Metabolic surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of bariatric surgery in a patient with obstructive sleep apnoea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Preoperative Assessment for Bariatric Surgery in Very Obese Patients

  • Very obese patients(e.g., with complications like sleep apnoea) require a careful multidisciplinary team (MDT) assessment.
  • Use of risk scoring systemshelps guide prognosis and decision-making:
    • Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS)
    • Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS)
  • OS-MRSassigns 1 point for each of the following risk factors:
    • Age ≥ 45 years
    • BMI ≥ 50
    • Male gender (linked to central obesity)
    • Hypertension (linked to central obesity)
    • Increased risk of DVT/PE
    • Higher scores indicate greater surgical risk

Risk Factors and Considerations:

  • Obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA):
    • Increases risk of anastomotic leak(per Swedish registry data)
    • Should be actively investigated and treated
    • CPAP therapy may reduce surgical risks
  • Uncontrolled diabetesis a general surgical risk factor and must be considered.

Preoperative Preparation:

  • A liver shrinkage diet (≥2 weeks) is routine before surgery:
    • Especially important with central obesity and an enlarged liver
    • Large livers can make surgery technically impossible
  • Failure to lose weight or follow the liver diet:
    • May signal underlying psychological barriers needing intervention

Arrhythmias (Option A): While OSA can contribute to cardiovascular strain and arrhythmias in general, arrhythmias are not the most common post-op complication in bariatric surgery patients with OSA

Post-operative bleeding (Option B): Bleeding is a known complication, but not specifically increased in patients with OSA.

Surgical site infections (Option C) or pneumonia can occur post-op, but again, not the most common complication in OSA patients.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient with a BMI > 50 kg/m2 and a patient suffering from hypertension. What should be the risk score for bariatric surgery according to the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The OS-MRS score for this patient is 4.

  • Age: 48 = 1 point
  • BMI > 50 kg/m2 = 1 point
  • Hypertension = 1 point
  • Male = 1point

Using risk scores such as the Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS) and Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS) can help the team discuss with patients the likely prognosis without surgery, and the risk of complications.

  • OS-MRSassigns 1 point for each of the following risk factors:
    • Age ≥ 45 years
    • BMI ≥ 50
    • Male gender (linked to central obesity)
    • Hypertension (linked to central obesity)
    • Increased risk of DVT/PE
    • Higher scores indicate greater surgical risk

Other risk factors:

  • Swedish registry data indicate that obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) is a risk factor for anastomotic leak.
  • Therefore, OSA should be actively investigated, as treatment with continuous positive airway pressure might reduce risk.
  • Uncontrolled diabetes must also be considered a risk factor, as it is for all other operations.

questions.text: Which cells in the stomach produce gastrin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the gastric antrum, the mucosa contains G cells, which produce gastrin.

Endocrine cells

  • The stomach has numerous endocrine cells, which are critical to its function.
  • In the gastric antrum, the mucosa contains G cells, which produce gastrin.
  • Throughout the body of the stomach, enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells are abundant and produce histamine, a key factor in driving gastric acid secretion.
  • In addition, there are large numbers of somatostatin-producing D cells throughout the stomach, and somatostatin has a negative regulatory role.

questions.text: Where are the Brunner's glands located in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brunner's glands are located in the duodenum.

  • The duodenum is lined by a mucus-secreting columnar epithelium.
  • In addition,Brunner's glands lie beneath the mucosa and are similar to the pyloric glands in the pyloric part of the stomach.
  • Endocrine cells in the duodenum produce cholecystokinin and secretin.

Large intestine (Option A) does not contain Brunner's glands. Instead, it has goblet cells that produce mucus to aid in the passage of stool, but it plays no role in acid neutralization.

Pylorus (Option B) is also incorrect; although it is the distal part of the stomach and does contain mucous glands, Brunner's glands begin only after the pylorus, in the duodenum.

Jejunum (Option D) is incorrect as well; the jejunum, which follows the duodenum, is primarily involved in nutrient absorption and does not contain Brunner's glands.

questions.text: Which among the following is the gold standard investigation of the upper gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:

  • Flexible endoscopy is the 'gold standard'investigation of the upper gastrointestinal tract.
  • The original flexible endoscopes were fibreoptic (Hirschowitz), but now most use a solid-state camera mounted at the instrument's tip.
  • Other members of the endoscopy team see the image, which is useful when taking biopsies or performing interventional techniques, and it also facilitates teaching and training.

questions.text: Which among the following tests is not used for detecting H. pylori infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Methylene blue is a general histological stain used in various microbiological and pathological procedures. It is not specific for detecting H. pylori.

Characteristics and Effects of H. pylori:

  • pylorican hydrolyse urea, producing ammonia, a strong alkali.
  • Ammonia stimulates antral G cellsto release gastrin via a negative-feedback loop.
  • This may lead to modest but inappropriate hypergastrinemia, contributing to gastric acid hypersecretionin peptic ulcer disease

Diagnostic Use of Urease Activity:

  • pylorihas obligate urease activity, which is used in diagnostic tests:
    • ¹³C and ¹⁴C urea breath tests(Option A)
    • CLO test (rapid urease test on gastric biopsy samples) (Option B)

Other Diagnostic Methods:

  • The organism can be detected histologicallyusing:
    • Giemsa stain
    • Warthin-Starry stain(Option C)
  • It can also be culturedusing appropriate media.
  • Serologycan detect past or current infection, but does not distinguish between them.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of occurrence of chronic gastritis due to H. pylori infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • pyloriinfection disrupts the gastric mucous barrier through enzymes produced by the organism.
  • This disruption leads to inflammation of the gastric epithelium, which underlies many associated disease processes

Disease Associations:

  • pyloriis strongly associated with chronic (type B) gastritis.
  • Certain strains produce cytotoxins, particularly CagAand VacA.
  • The presence of these cytotoxins is linked to increased risk of:
    • Gastritis
    • Peptic ulcer disease
    • Gastric cancer

Inflammatory Response:

  • The organism induces a classical inflammatory responsein the gastric epithelium.
  • This involves:
    • Migration and degranulation of neutrophils(acute inflammation)

Accumulation of macrophages and lymphocytes (chronic inflammation)

questions.text: Which is the most common area affected by type B gastritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type B gastritis most commonly affects the antrum of the stomach.

  • pylori gastritisis commonly referred to as antral-predominant gastritis, formerly known as type B gastritis.
  • It primarily affects the antrum of the stomach, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer disease.
  • While inflammation of the entire stomach (pangastritis)is frequently seen in pylori infection, isolated inflammation of the gastric corpus is rare.
  • Chronic pangastritis, especially when it leads to glandular atrophy, can progress to intestinal metaplasia.
  • If intestinal metaplasiais accompanied by dysplasia, there is a significant risk of gastric cancer.
  • In individuals with high-risk features, endoscopic surveillancemay be warranted for early detection of malignancy.

The fundus (Option A) is the upper portion of the stomach. It is more commonly affected in autoimmune (type A) gastritis, not type B. Type A gastritis targets parietal cells in the fundus and body, leading to atrophy and pernicious anemia.

The lesser curvature (Option B) is a specific location on the stomach, not a region like the antrum or fundus. While H. pylori may sometimes be found here, it is not the primary or most commonly affected area in type B gastritis.

Similar to the lesser curvature, the greater curvature (Option C) is a part of the stomach's anatomy, but not typically the primary site for H. pylori-induced gastritis. The antrum remains the main site for early infection and inflammation

questions.text: Which is the common site for a peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peptic ulcers most frequently develop in the first part of the duodenum and along the lesser curvature of the stomach.

They may also form in less common locations, such as:

  • The anastomosis siteafter gastric surgery (surgical stoma)
  • The oesophagus
  • A Meckel's diverticulum, particularly when it contains ectopic gastric mucosa
  • Ulcers typically arise at transitional zones-areas where different epithelial types
  • The ulcer tends to occur in the type of epithelium that is less resistant to acid, making it more vulnerable to damage.

questions.text: Which artery is eroded by the posterior part of the kissing ulcer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most duodenal ulcersdevelop in the first part of the duodenum.
  • Chronic ulcerscan erode through the mucosa into the muscular layer, triggering a healing response that leads to fibrosis.
  • This fibrotic scarringmay result in structural complications such as pyloric stenosis.
  • When ulcers heal, visible mucosal scarringmay remain as evidence of prior damage.
  • In some cases, multiple ulcersmay be present in the duodenum. When both an anterior and posterior ulcer are found simultaneously, the condition is known as "kissing ulcers."
  • Anterior duodenal ulcersare more prone to perforation, whereas posterior ulcers are more likely to bleed, especially if they erode into the gastroduodenal artery.
  • Occasionally, the ulceration can be so widespread that the entire duodenal capbecomes ulcerated, with complete loss of mucosal lining.
  • In the case of a giant duodenal ulcer, malignancy is rarein this region, so surgeons generally assume the lesion is benign, even if its appearance on palpation seems concerning.
  • However, the stomachpresents a different scenario, where malignant ulcers are a more significant consideration.

The splenic artery (Option A) runs along the superior border of the pancreas and supplies the spleen and parts of the stomach, especially the fundus. It may be involved in posterior gastric ulcers, but not duodenal ulcers.

Hepatic artery (Option B): While it is in the vicinity of the upper gastrointestinal tract, it is not adjacent to the posterior duodenum, so it is not typically affected by duodenal ulcers.

Superior mesenteric artery (Option D): It is not anatomically related to the posterior wall of the duodenum and is not involved in bleeding from duodenal ulcers.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duodenal ulcer is more common in males than in females.

  • In the last two decades, there have been notable changes in the presentation and demographicsof duodenal ulcer disease in resource-rich countries.
  • Even beforethe introduction of H₂-receptor antagonists, both the:

questions.text: Which among the following gastrointestinal ulcers is not associated with malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic duodenal ulcers are not associated with malignancy whereas gastric ulcers are.

Assessment and Management of Gastric Ulcers:

  • Determining whether a gastric lesionis benign or malignant depends heavily on the experience and judgement of the endoscopist or radiologist.
  • As a general rule, all gastric ulcers should be considered potentially malignantuntil proven otherwise, even if they appear to have features typical of benign ulcers. (Option A)
  • To ensure accurate diagnosis, it is recommended to take multiple biopsies-often up to 10 well-targeted samples-before making a tentative diagnosis of a benign ulcer.
  • It's important to note that modern acid-suppressing drugs(such as PPIs or H₂-blockers) can lead to healing of ulcers, including those caused by gastric cancer. However, while the ulcer may heal, the underlying malignancy remains untreated.

Other Types of Peptic Ulcers:

  • Pre-pyloric ulcers, once difficult to manage, are now effectively treatedwith proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).
  • Pyloric channel ulcersclosely resemble duodenal ulcers in terms of their presentation and behavior.
  • Both pre-pyloricand pyloric ulcers carry a risk of malignancy, making biopsy essential for accurate diagnosis. (Option B & D)
  • Stomal ulcersoccur after certain types of gastric surgery:
    • Most commonly after a gastroenterostomy(now often performed during bariatric surgery),
    • Or following a Billroth II gastrectomy.
    • These ulcers typically develop on the jejunal side of the surgical connection (stoma).

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for a peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastroduodenoscopy

  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopyis the preferred investigation for suspected peptic ulcer disease, offering high sensitivity and specificity when performed by an experienced clinician.
  • During endoscopy of the stomach, any suspicious lesionshould be sampled thoroughly. Even if a gastric ulcer appears benign, multiple biopsies are essential to help rule out underlying malignancy.
  • Antral biopsiesare commonly taken to:
    • Evaluate for histological signs of gastritis.
    • Conduct a CLO (rapid urease) testto detect pylori infection.
  • A "U-turn" (retroflexion) manoeuvreshould be done to inspect the gastro-oesophageal junction, where malignancies are increasingly common. Any abnormal mucosa in this area should be biopsied thoroughly.
  • In patients who have had previous gastric surgery (e.g. gastroenterostomyor Billroth II gastrectomy), it's important to examine both the afferent and efferent limbs of the surgical stoma.
  • Stomal ulcersare typically located near the transition zone between gastric and jejunal mucosa, so this area requires particular attention.
  • Examination of the pyloric regionis crucial to assess for:
    • Presence of pre-pyloric or pyloric channel ulcers.
    • Evidence of deformity, which is a common finding in long-standing duodenal ulcer disease.
  • In the duodenum, the entire first portionshould be carefully inspected, as ulcers can be located just beyond the pylorus and may be easily missed if not examined thoroughly.

questions.text: Which anastomosis is performed in Billroth-II surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Billroth II (Pólya) Gastrectomy

  • In a Billroth II gastrectomy, or its variation, the Pólya gastrectomy, the distal stomach, including the antrum and lower body, is surgically removed.
  • To mobilise the stomach for resection, the greater and lesser omentum are divided, and the following vessels are ligated:
    • Gastroepiploic arteries
    • Right gastric artery
    • Left gastric artery arcadeat the resection margin.
  • The duodenum is then closed, either with sutures or stapling devices. This step can be technically challenging, particularly in cases where the duodenum is distorted or fibrotic.
  • After removal of the gastric segment:
    • The lesser curvatureof the remaining stomach is partially closed to narrow the distal end.
    • The greater curvatureis then anastomosed to the jejunum, typically in a retrocolic configuration, with efforts made to keep the afferent loop as short as possible.

Complications and Considerations:

  • A notable risk is leakage from the duodenal stump, which can occur especially if the afferent loop becomes kinked, creating pressure on the stump.
  • Anastomotic leaksat the gastrojejunostomy site are less common, but may occur if:
    • The connection is under excessive tension, or
    • The blood supply to the gastric remnant is compromisedduring mobilisation.
  • Ulcer recurrenceat the anastomosis is infrequent but still possible-especially since vagotomy is not routinely included in this procedure.
  • In modern surgical practice, many specialist centres now prefer the Roux-en-Y reconstructionover Billroth II, due to its better postoperative physiological function and lower complication rate.

Gastroduodenostomy (Option A): This is the anastomosis used in a Billroth I procedure, not Billroth II. In Billroth I, the stomach is reconnected directly to the duodenum. Since Billroth II bypasses the duodenum, this is not the correct choice.

Duodenojejunostomy (Option C): This involves connecting the duodenum to the jejunum, often used in conditions like duodenal obstruction (e.g., in SMA syndrome). It is not part of Billroth II, where the duodenum is closed off.

Oesophagojejunostomy (Option D): This is used when the entire stomach is removed (e.g., total gastrectomy). The oesophagus is then connected directly to the jejunum. It has no role in Billroth II, where a portion of the stomach is preserved.

questions.text: Which cells of the stomach are denervated in highly selective vagotomy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The parietal cells of the stomach are denerved in highly selective vagotomy.

Highly selective vagotomy

  • In 1968, both Johnston and Amdrupindependently introduced the technique of highly selective vagotomy (HSV), targeting only the nerve supply to the parietal (acid-secreting) region of the stomach.
  • This approach became the preferred surgical treatmentfor duodenal ulcer disease, particularly throughout the 1970s, due to its effectiveness and minimal complications when performed precisely.
  • Unlike other vagotomy procedures, HSV preserved the rest of the stomach's innervation, reducing many of the common side effects associated with peptic ulcer surgeries.
  • The recurrence rateof ulcers was considered acceptable, especially when the operation was technically well executed.
  • One of its major advantages was a lower mortality rate, likely because the gastrointestinal tract remained unopened, reducing surgical risk.
  • Most of the postoperative complicationslinked to ulcer surgeries, such as severe dumping syndrome or diarrhea, were significantly reduced with HSV.
  • However, some patients did experience loss of receptive relaxation in the stomach, leading to epigastric discomfort or a sensation of fullness, and occasionally mild dumping symptoms.

questions.text: Which is the preferred surgery for bile vomiting after vagotomy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Roux-en-Y diversion is the best treatment for bile vomiting after vagotomy.

  • Bile vomiting can occur after any form of vagotomy with drainage or gastrectomy.
  • Commonly, the patient presents with vomiting a mixture of food and bile or sometimes some bile alone after a meal.
  • Often, eating will precipitate abdominal pain, and reflux symptoms are common.
  • Bile chelating agents can be tried, but are usually ineffective.
  • In intractable cases, revisional surgery may be indicated.
  • The nature of that revisional surgery depends very much on the original operation.
  • Following gastrectomy, Roux-en-Y diversion is probably the best treatment.
  • In patients with a gastroenterostomy, this can be taken down and, in most circumstances, a small pyloroplasty can be performed.
  • In patients with a pyloroplasty, reconstruction of the pylorus has been attempted, but, in general terms, the results of this operation have been rather poor.
  • Antrectomy and Roux-en-Y reconstruction may be the better option.

questions.text: Which among the following is not the metabolic change in gastric outlet obstruction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastric outlet obstruction is associated with hopokalemia.

Metabolic effects of gastric outlet obstruction:

  • Persistent vomiting of gastric acidleads to a hypochloraemic metabolic alkalosis, as the body loses both hydrogen and chloride ions. (Option A)
  • In the early stages, levels of sodium and potassiumin the blood may appear relatively unaffected.
  • As dehydrationbecomes more severe, metabolic imbalances worsen, partly due to the kidneys' reduced ability to regulate electrolytes.
  • Initially, urine shows:
    • Low chloride levels
    • High bicarbonate levels:This reflects the ongoing alkalosis, where bicarbonate is lost through urine, accompanied by sodium, gradually leading to hyponatraemia and worsening dehydration. (Option C)
  • In response to volume depletion, the kidneys start to retain sodium.
  • To do this, they increase the excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, causing:
    • Paradoxical aciduria (acidic urine despite systemic alkalosis)
    • Hypokalaemia (vs Option B)
  • The alkalotic statealso reduces free (ionised) calcium levels in the bloodstream, which can lead to tetany in some cases. (Option D)

questions.text: Which are the two fixed points around which the stomach rotates in the volvulus of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Volvulus of the stomach

  • Rotation of the stomach usually occurs around the axis and between its two fixed points, i.e., the cardia and the pylorus.
  • In theory, rotation can occur in the horizontal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) direction, but commonly, it is the former which occurs.
  • This condition is usually associated with a large diaphragmatic defect around the oesophagus (paraesophageal herniation).

questions.text: Which among the following is not the boundary of the gastrinoma triangle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastrinomas may occur as isolated (sporadic) tumors or be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type I (MEN I), an autosomal dominant condition. In MEN I, parathyroid adenomas are a common co-existing feature.

  • These tumors are typically located within the so-called 'gastrinoma triangle' (Passaro's triangle), an anatomical region bounded by:
    • The junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct(superior border) (Option A)
    • The point where the second and third parts of the duodenum meet(inferior border) (Option D)
    • The junction of the neck and body of the pancreas, near the superior mesenteric artery(medial border) (Option C)
  • A significant number of gastrinomas are found in the duodenal loop, likely originating from G cellswithin Brunner's glands.
  • Accurate identification of these tumors requires meticulous examinationof the duodenal wall, both during endoscopy and surgical exploration. Often, only a small nodule projecting from the medial aspect of the duodenum is visible, making detection challenging.

questions.text: What is the margin of resection in a case of gastric cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to standard surgical principles, at least 5 cm of grossly tumour-free margin is recommended.

  • In surgical management of gastric cancer, it is crucial to achieve clear resection marginsto reduce the risk of local recurrence and improve long-term outcomes.
  • According to standard surgical principles, at least 5 cmof grossly tumour-free margin is recommended during total gastrectomy.
  • This applies to both proximal and distal margins.
  • If there is any doubt about whether margins are clear, a frozen sectionshould be performed intraoperatively to confirm the absence of cancer cells.

questions.text: Which among the following is not the modality for staging carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Barium meal is not a reliable modality for staging carcinoma.

Preoperative Staging in Gastric Adenocarcinoma

  • The primary goals of preoperative staging in gastric adenocarcinoma are to assess prognosis, guide patient counseling, and determine the extent of disease to select the most appropriate treatment strategy.

There are three principal treatment pathways:

  • Upfront surgical resection, with or without subsequent adjuvant therapy,
  • Neoadjuvant therapyfollowed by surgical resection, and
  • Systemic therapy alonefor patients with unresectable or metastatic disease.
  • Accurate staging is essential to select among these options and avoid non-beneficial surgery.
  • The key modalities used in the staging process include:
    • Upper endoscopy, for direct visualization and biopsy of the tumor (Option B)
    • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), for assessing the depth of tumor invasion (T stage) and local nodal involvement (Option A)
    • Cross-sectional imaging, such as computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and/or positron emission tomography (PET), to evaluate regional and distant disease spread (Option D)
    • Diagnostic laparoscopy, particularly for detecting peritoneal metastases not visible on imaging, can upstage disease and alter management

questions.text: Which layer is denoted as the fourth layer of the stomach in the endoscopic ultrasound technique?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • EUS is recommended by NCCN guidelines as part of the staging workup for gastric cancer if there is no evidence of metastatic disease.
  • EUS provides the most accurate evaluation of the depth of tumor invasion, assessment of perigastric lymph node involvement, and can sometimes identify involvement of surrounding organs or the presence of ascites.
  • EUS is performed using a flexible endoscope with a 7.5- to 12-MHz ultrasound transducer. The stomach is filled with water to provide an acoustic window, and the stomach wall is visualized as five alternating hypoechoic and hyperechoic layers.
  • The mucosa and submucosa represent the first three layers (T1).
  • The fourth layer is the muscularis propria, invasion of which signifies a T2 tumor.
  • Expansion of the tumor beyond the muscularis propria causing an irregular border correlates with expansion into the subserosa, or a T3 tumor.
  • The serosa is the fifth layer, and loss of this bright line correlates with penetration through it, indicating a T4a tumor.
  • Direct invasion of surrounding structures, including named vessels, indicates a T4b tumor.
  • Nodes are evaluated based on their size and ultrasound appearance and can additionally be sampled using fine-needle aspiration (FNA) under EUS guidance.
  • FNA can also be performed if ascites is present to evaluate for peritoneal spread.
